authorblurb.para: Paul Klint, Centrum voor Wiskunde en Informatica, Amsterdam, The Netherlands

section.title: Background
section.para: The ASF+SDF Meta-Environment is an interactive development environment for

defining domain-specific languages and the tools to support them, and
performing analysis and transformation existing software.
See www.meta-environment.org for further details. We are planning to organize the development of this system in the fashion of an open source project. First of all, we will relabel the project as "OpenMetaEnvironment" (Is this the best name?). Next we need to present our documentation in a coherent fashion. The purpose of the current document is twofold:

listitem.para: to describe a general documentation policy for the OpenMetaEnvironment, and
to make a selection of tools and techniques that can be used to implement this policy.

section.title: Current situation
section.para: Currently, we use the following mechanisms to document (parts of) the system:

listitem.para: Scientific papers that describe specific techniques or case studies.

LaTex documents to describe either the whole system (e.g. user manual) or specific tools or libraries (e.g., aterm library, toolbus). HyperLatex is being used for generating web pages from LaTex files.
POD files for manual pages.
API documentation generated with javadoc.
Web pages in our SEN1 twiki.

section.title: The ideal situation
section.para: Ideally, we want to present all information about our system in a unified manner. This includes:

listitem.para: High-level descriptions of purpose and architecture
For each package we need:
A global description of purpose and main use cases.
A manpage-like description of command-line use of that package.
Description of the APIs provided by the package.
A User manual that describes user-interface and common tasks.
An implementors manual.
Helpfiles.
Download area with instructions.
Description of the licenses we are using.
Access to bugtracker.
Access to SVN repository.
Access to mailing lists.

section.title: How to get there?
section.para: It seems that the most widely used technology for documenting software projects is DocBook (see, www.docbook.org). Docbook is an XML-based standard for the semantic mark-up of text and can be used to generate a wide variety of output formats including HTML, PDF, man pages, javahelp, and eclipsehelp. This means that we can use a single source for our webpages, interactive help and printed documentation.

The downside of using DocBook is that we have to learn yet another text processing technology. The number of predefined tags in DocBook is large (400) and the markup is more verbose than, for instance, LaTex.
I have tried a number of DocBook editors including:

listitem.para: The xxe editor by XMLMind (www.xmlmind.com/xmleditor). The standard edition of xxe is freely available.
The Eclipse-based editor Vex (vex.sourceforge.net).
The conglomerate editor (www.conglomerate.org).
The nXML extention of emacs (hacks.oreilly.com/pub/h/2044).
The DocBook extension of openoffice (xml.openoffice.org/xmerge/docbook/index.html).

section.para: Based on this experience I recommend to use xxe for wysiwyg editing and emacs for editing of the XML source.

section.title: DocBook resources

listitem.para: www.docbook.org (see in particular the DocBook wiki at wiki.docbook.org with many tutorials, tools and examples)
The DocBook project (docbook.sourceforge.net)

section.para: Useful books related to DocBook are:

listitem.para: N. Walsh and L. Mueller, DocBook: The Definitive Guide, O'Reilly, 1999. See also www.docbook.org/tdg.
Bob Stayton, DocBook XSL, The Complete Guide, Sagehill, 2005. See also www.sagehill.net/docbookxsl.
Switch to DocBook for writing all documentation.
Existing documentation will be converted to DocBook.
Existing javadoc documentation in Java will be rendered by Doxygen and included in the Twiki pages.
For all non-java documentation, we will start to write Doxygen comments.
Add a doc target to all our packages and include the documentation in the website.
Man pages and API documentation will be included in each package.
More global documents will be included in the meta-doc package.
Extend meta-studio with a java help browser. See http www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/2003/10/15/javahelp_docbook.html
